title: Intrauterine RBC Transfusion Dosage
description: Estimates volume of donor RBCs needed for intrauterine transfusion (IUT) in fetal anemia cases. Used primarily for severe fetal anemia in hemolytic disease of the fetus and newborn (HDFN) when maternal RBC alloantibodies threaten fetal health. Calculates precise transfusion volume to achieve target hematocrit while minimizing risks of over- or under-transfusion.

parameters.name: fetal_weight_g
parameters.description: Estimated fetal weight in grams based on biometric measurements from ultrasound

parameters.name: initial_hematocrit
parameters.description: Current fetal hematocrit percentage before transfusion

parameters.name: goal_hematocrit
parameters.description: Target fetal hematocrit percentage after transfusion (usually 40-45%)

parameters.name: transfused_hematocrit
parameters.description: Hematocrit percentage of the donor RBC unit to be transfused (typically 75-85%)

result.name: transfusion_volume
result.description: Volume of donor RBCs needed for intrauterine transfusion

ranges.interpretation: Small volume transfusion appropriate for early gestational age or mild anemia. Monitor closely for response and avoid volume overload.
Moderate volume transfusion typical for established fetal anemia. Standard monitoring protocols apply with assessment of fetal well-being.
Large volume transfusion for severe anemia or larger fetuses. Requires careful monitoring for circulatory overload and may need staged transfusions.

references: Mandelbrot L, Daffos F, Forestier F, MacAleese J, Descamps P. Assessment of fetal blood volume for computer-assisted management of in utero transfusion. Fetal Ther. 1988;3(1-2):60-6.
Liley AW. Intrauterine transfusion of foetus in haemolytic disease. Br Med J. 1963;2(5365):1107-9.
Society for Maternal-Fetal Medicine (SMFM). Management of alloimmunization during pregnancy. Am J Obstet Gynecol. 2018;218(2):B7-B18.

Van Kamp IL, Klumper FJ, Oepkes D, Meerman RH, Scherjon SA, Vandenbussche FP, et al. Complications of intrauterine intravascular transfusion for fetal anemia due to maternal red-cell alloimmunization. Am J Obstet Gynecol. 2005;192(1):171-7.
formula: Transfusion volume (mL) = Fetoplacental volume × [Hct(goal) - Hct(initial)] / Hct(transfused); Fetoplacental volume = fetal weight (g) × 0.14 mL/g
notes: Used primarily for hemolytic disease of the fetus and newborn (HDFN) due to maternal alloantibodies
Fetoplacental volume estimated as 14% of fetal weight (0.14 mL/g)
Donor RBCs should be CMV-negative, irradiated, and compatible with maternal serum
Requires specialized maternal-fetal medicine expertise and ultrasound guidance
Monitor for complications including fetal bradycardia, bleeding, and infection
Consider serial transfusions for severe cases or if single transfusion volume is excessive
